raw_affiliation_strings: Frick Chemical Laboratory, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544

Walter Kauzmann is Professor of Chemistry Emeritus at Princeton University, where he received his Ph.D. in 1940. He rose through the ranks to Professor (1960), but in the intervening period he was Westing-house Research Fellow, and served on the Manhattan Project. At Princeton University, he was Chairman of the Department of Chemistry (1964–1968) and Chairman of the Department of Biochemical Sciences (1980–1982). Dr. Kauzmann is a member of the National Academy of Sciences and a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and recently was awarded an Honorary Ph.D. degree by the University of Stockholm. He is recipient of the Linderstrøm-Lang Medal (1966) and will receive the Stein and Moore Award of The Protein Society in 1993. His research interests range from quantum chemistry, optical rotatory power, high-pressure physical chemistry, and mechanism of conversion of chemical to mechanical energy, to the physical chemistry of proteins and the history and philosophy of science. Among protein chemists, he is best known for his pioneering studies of the contributions of hydrophobic interactions to the structure of proteins.
